column1: The lasting appeal of Pride and Prejudice is worth explaining to those who haven't read the book or seen the movies before launching into a review of this British classic.  First
column2: there may be no finer book at exploring the topic of how appearances can be deceiving.  Those who are physically attractive
column3: employ pleasant manners and flatter us will earn our approval and cause us to feel affectionate towards them.  Those who are less attractive to regard
column4: keep to themselves and say insulting things will become people we will think poorly of.  To see how misleading those reactions can be in assessing character
column5: compare Abraham Lincoln to Jefferson Davis
column6: the head of the Confederacy.  Lincoln was dour
column7: ugly and awkward with people.  Jefferson Davis was just the opposite.  When it came to character
column8: Lincoln had enough to hold the Union together and is now viewed as one of our greatest presidents.  Most people don't remember Jefferson Davis unless reminded.    Second
column9: at another level Pride and Prejudice is a delightful romantic comedy that looks at how love develops through a series of painful mischances.  Although not as light and funny as Shakespeare's comedies are (A Midsummer Night's Dream comes to mind)
column10: Pride and Prejudice will certainly bring a smile to most readers' faces in this regard.  Third
column11: Elizabeth Bennet is one of the best heroines ever imagined.  Most readers will identify with her and be rooting for her to succeed.  You'll almost feel like you've developed a good friend from reading this book.  Fourth
column12: Jane Austen is very good at poking fun at the pretensions of those who are self-absorbed or fascinated with social position and money.  But it's a loving kind of fun.  She realizes that these people are just silly . . . and don't know any better.  We can enjoy a good laugh at their expense
column13: but we should still love and support them.  It's a good model for dealing with any goofy relatives we have.    Fifth
column14: Pride and Prejudice is a benchmark at how far women have come from the days when they often couldn't even inherit property from their fathers.  You'll be as outraged as Mrs. Bennet is at these anachronisms . . . but you'll be assuaged to know that the worst of those bad old days are behind us.    So
column15: if those reasons to read Pride and Prejudice appeal to you
column16: read on as I briefly describe the story.  The Bennets have a challenge:  They have five unmarried daughters who cannot inherit Mr. Bennet's entailed estate.  With few prospects in the neighborhood
column17: Mrs. Bennet is always on the hunt.  Mr. Bennet views Mrs. Bennet's fascination with this challenge as being something he would like to distance himself from.    When an eligible young man moves into the area
column18: Mrs. Bennet's instincts are engaged to the fullest.  One of her daughters must marry Mr. Bingley.  At the next ball
column19: the pickings seem to improve when Mr. Bingley arrives with a friend
column20: Mr. Darcy.  Darcy  "soon drew the attention of the room by his fine tall person
column21: handsome features
column22: noble mien; and the report . . . of his having ten thousand a year."  But Mr. Darcy soon turned the fortune hunters off by only dancing with his sisters and refusing to be introduced to any of the other ladies.   Bingley finds himself very attracted to Jane Bennet and their relationship develops nicely . . . until he leaves suddenly for London with no plans to return.  Jane waits for some news from him or his sisters and finds herself being cut off.    In the middle of this
column23: Mr. Collins arrives.  Collins will inherit Mr. Bennet's property upon his death.  He has just received a position as a clergyman from a powerful and opinionated sponsor
column24: Lady Catherine de Bourgh
column25: and she has told him to get married.  With four unmarried cousins
column26: Collins decides the Bennet daughters are his best bet.  In this way
column27: he can provide a home for them and their mother after he inherits.  First being inspired by Jane
column28: he redirects his attention to Elizabeth after perceiving Jane's interest in Bingley and quickly proposes.  Elizabeth will have none of it
column29: and Collins soon finds a more enthusiastic prospect in another local family.   The younger sisters are finding themselves more than entertained by the dashing officers in a local regiment.  Through this connection
column30: Elizabeth becomes acquainted with Wickham who confides in her that Mr. Darcy had treated Wickham with great unfairness after Mr. Darcy's father's death.  That's just one more nail in the coffin for the case against Mr. Darcy.  But in the background
column31: we get hints that something is shifting.  Mr. Darcy goes from finding Elizabeth to be ordinary in appearance to commenting favorably about one small aspect of her face
column32: her mouth.  But put the two of them together
column33: and civil words do not follow.  They are like oil and water.    Jane and Elizabeth eventually make it to London where both hope that Jane will reconnect with Bingley.  But no such luck.  Just when things seem to be headed in a most bleak direction
column34: a terrible event occurs that shakes everyone like an enormous earthquake.  In its aftermath
column35: each character finds herself or himself needed to re-examine their position and perceptions of one another.  Will Jane and Bingley connect with one another again?  Will Elizabeth find happiness?  Will Mrs. Bennet marry her daughters off?  You'll just have to read the book to find out.  But unlike modern novelists
column36: remember that Jane Austen wasn't against happy endings.  Enjoy a great read!

column1: The Lotus Sutra
column2: or Scripture of the Lotus Blossom of the Fine Dharma  (J.
column3: Myohorengekyo
column4: Hokkekyo)
column5: the preeminent scripture in the Mahayana Buddhism of East Asia -- China
column6: Tibet
column7: Mongolia
column8: Korea
column9: Japan
column10: and Vietnam -- is known primarily through the translation into Chinese of the Sanskrit Saddharma-pundarika-sutra by Kumarajiva in CE 406. (This 28-chapter version differs in organization and presentation from the 27-chapter Sanskrit text translated into English by H. Kern in 1884
column11: and still available for sale; the two versions should not be confused.)   Although Kumarajiva's Lotus Sutra has influenced all of Japanese Buddhism in one way or another
column12: it is the basic scripture for the great medieval Tendai (C.
column13: T'ien T'ai) sect
column14: as well as the later Nichiren sect and its offshoots
column15: especially Soka Gakkai and Rissho Koseikai
column16: all three of which emphasize recitation of the "Nam' myohorengekyo" formula."  The Lotus is NOT included in the scriptural canon of Southern Buddhism (Theravada) in Sri Lanka
column17: Burma
column18: Thailand
column19: and other areas of SE Asia.  The Lotus Sutra is basically a statement of philosophical principles and should not be approached as literary entertainment.  Its message has serious implications - today probably more so than any time in past history.  But the reading takes patience and serious
column20: quiet rumination.  Its message is that all sentient beings have the potential for attaining Buddhahood
column21: but conceptual illusion prevents them from realizing that this is their essential nature.  Out of compassion
column22: the Buddha(s) employs many devices (Skillful Means/Expedients; hoben) accommodated to their specific needs
column23: to assist them in seeing through this illusion. (The notion is expressed through most of the sutra's Seven Parables.)  Although provisional teachings are not only possible but necessary
column24: there is
column25: in fact
column26: only One Vehicle
column27: one ultimate
column28: ineffable spiritual goal; and for this reason the Lotus is sometimes called the Sutra of the One Vehicle. It is important to note
column29: however
column30: that the term does not describe an EXCLUSIVE DOGMATIC FORMULATION that is taken to be correct while others are false.  The ultimate religious experience is beyond the reach of rational understanding
column31: which is
column32: at best
column33: "a finger pointing at the moon".   Although the Lotus Sutra might be viewed as the BEST possible expression of the Buddha's teaching
column34: it is NOT THE ONE AND ONLY way to spiritual realization: other scriptures (and other words
column35: rituals
column36: myths
column37: metaphors
column38: etc.) can be embraced as expressing a more or less adequate means for attaining spiritual understanding - the specific words or symbols do no matter. The One Vehicle refers to a single experiential GOAL to be reached through a variety of conceptual formulations and exercises
column39: but ultimately transcending the word-games of rationality. Note
column40: however
column41: that although the Lotus Sutra freely admits many routes to enlightenment (because of the varying needs of individuals)
column42: it does NOT claim that "one view is just as good as any another
column43:
i.e., relativism.  Although today the most popular translation of the (Chinese) Lotus Sutra may be Burton Watson's elegant rendition (1993) into English, some serious scholars still prefer this older version by Leon Hurvitz (1976); and even, occasionally, the Bunno Kato collection of three sutras (1975). Depending on the size of your wallet, you might consider buying all 3.  
 I've been a fan of Aerosmith for about 20 years.  This collection is a great way to be introduced to the band, and also a great collection for the hard-core fan 
 This is one of the most inspiring books I have ever read.  Hochschild tells an important story very powerfully and with great feeling and humanity.  And he has some facinating heroes and villains, because this is a tale of human beings at our very best and at our very worst.  Hochschild shows us the developing moral insight of abolitionist leaders like Thomas Clarkson, Granville Sharpe and the Quakers, who somehow understood something early on that was unclear to many Britons: that slavery was evil.  He also limns the amazing life of Olaudah Equiano, who knew slavery from personal experience, and shows how a small group was able to move millions of people its cause--and even get hundreds of thousands to give up sugar in their tea.  Also--and very importantly--Hochschild shows how eventual emancipation was not a gift from European and American humanitarians, but at least partially the result of a long struggle in the slave colonies by the slaves themselves, generations of whom proved willing, again and again, to die for their freedom.  It is interesting that the slave revolts in the West Indies were often a setback in public opinion for the British abolitionists: apparently it was easier to accept the idea that slavery was evil than it was to get to the idea that slaves have an inherent right of armed resistance.  Meticulous and detailed research and a passionate yet thoughtful writing style are great strengths of this book.  Hard to put down, and hard to stop thinking about even months after finishing it

His writings help to rediscover prayer, meditation, and the Divine Center"  necessary for walking daily with Christ...  This is a book to read and re-read.  It is one gift that any Christian would find liberating and inspirin

column1: Dr. King in this book
column2: gives the background on the successful demonstrations in Birmingham and The  1963 March on Washington. (My father was at that march). Martin gives the insights on his Non -violent Direct Action approach and how it worked in Birmingham. He also explains what he meant in his I have a dream speech. Those who read this book will see that Dr. King favored a approach to bring African-Americans in the Mainstream that is similiar to Affirmative Action. Dr. King's mistakes were he assumed the whites in the North would favor his approach when he came to their neighborhood (Chicago 1966)and that those who favored ending segregation would support spending government money to help poor Blacks. All Americans should read this book

The single white character on stage in South African-born playright Athol Fugard's one-scene work is the friend of his mother's two black employees when they tend to St George's Park Tearoom in her absence.  But he is also their 'Master Harold'-reluctantly but inevitably-when the stress of his crippled
column3: alcoholic father's homecoming impels him into an emotional space that one simply does not share with black folks.  Perhaps is it the burden of dealing with human beings on the multiple levels that racism forces upon those who resent but ultimately accede to their required roles that embitters Hally beyond redemption.  Hally doesn't know several things.  He is ignorant of the nobility with which Sam and Willie have battled for his dignity over the years of service to his family.  He doesn't understand that even this virtue has its limits
column4: beyond which dignity weighs more than the possibility of continuing friendship.  Hally doesn't understand that a night of dancing at the Eastern Province Open Dancing Championships is a thing of beauty rather than of entertainment

column1: As the liner notes say this album certainly does show Soft Machine changing. The album is well produced and nicely packaged. Disc 1 starts us off with a hazy version of As If with Phil Howard going crazy on drums instead of John Marshall.Also different from the song is the echo sax by Elton Dean and no solo by Roy Babbington. Drop sound just like it does on Fifth not that much over dubbing on it. The unreleased Welcome To Frillsville is a long jam with Howard actually keeping a beat
column2: the end product of the song is a lovely smooth jazz theme. Then we see Karl Jenkins and John Marshall in for Dean and Howard. The Melody features a great version of MC and Drop
column3: All White is the same as the version on Six. Stanley Stamps is played with a synth in the backgound
column4: pretty good too. And the starting of a great tune of Hazard Profile actually has a better lead on the beginning rift instead of those one line notes on the other Profile. Disc 2 has the Baritone Guitar solo of Babbington with turns into the relaxing recorder and sax lead of Down the Road still no Acostic Bass solo by Babbington. North Point is a cross between D.I.S and Four Gongs with some messy synth. The smoothness of The Man Who Waved at Trains also has Peff with out the guitar rift at the end. Then we go to the finale Hazard Profile which has a different middle part with out the organ lines being in charge on chord changes. And part 5 is in there but Ratlegdge's solo is on organ not a analog synth. If you got $30  (rip-off) go out and buy this masterpiece.

column1: Really this gets 3.5 stars
column2: a compromise between its shortcomings and its strengths. I round up because it's extremely readable and informative and its flaws don't detract from these qualities. Basically what we have here is a critical (but far from apologetic) look back on the Sixties student movement from someone who was on the inside. There are fairly perceptive glances here and there to other aspects of the era's counterculture and political movement but the outlook is basically limited to that of the SDS "Old Guard" (the student activists eager to proclaim radical politics since the Kennedy era
column3: when said politics were still unfashionable).   Though this group was to be at the center of the late sixties rebellion
column4: the title is a bit deceiving--this isn't an overview of the decade
column5: per se but rather the decade as Todd Gitlin saw if from his perch in SDS. That's part of the problem with the book
column6: because Gitlin veers back and forth between historical recollection/analysis and personal memories without really choosing which he wants to develop--and both suffer as a result (the memoir aspect most of all). We get only a vague idea of what his role in all of this was and throughout much of the book he seems more like an observor than an active participant. But then that seems to be true of the New Left as a whole. They were vainly (in both senses of the word) talking sense to power in the early years
column7: unable to connect with the counterculture of mid-decade
column8: and then dissolving into squabbling factions hedonistically pursuing revolution by '69. I for one got the sense that the SDS' power was greatly exaggerated
column9: both by itself and by the opposition. SDS seems to have been the proverbial tail that thinks it's wagging the dog
column10: as Gitlin comes close to pointing out a few times. His memories add to the sense that he
column11: and the old SDSers
column12: spent most of the decade either cheerleading or wringing their hands at the various actors on the political stage
column13: from SNCC to the Black Panthers
column14: the Diggers to the Yippies
column15: the more radical students to the eventually psychotic Weather Underground
column16: often ignoring the more mainstream peace movement to the liberal politicians who were the actual movers and shakers. Perhaps Gitlin gives himself and SDS short shrift by focusing on all the different movements and trends sweeping the 60's
column17: but if so I would've liked to see a book recounting HIS experiences of the 60's.   Then again
column18: maybe it's just one of those "contradictions" he speaks of late in the book. His memories
column19: like being aided by Democratic delegates in the middle of the Chicago confrontation-or of a bunch of uptight student radicals being confronted by the charismatic revolutionary Diggers) add color to the recounted political theater of the times and ultimately
column20: both are just as indispensible as they are problematic. Ultimately
column21: I have to recommend this book because of its coherent analysis of different 60's factions that too often get clumped together (many times have I heard Bernardine Dohrn's Charles Manson comments held up as if they were representative of the entire student Left). Be aware that the book is not a comprehensive overview of those years
column22: it very much takes the "Old Guard" (i.e.
column23: involved since the early 60's) radical student view of things
column24: and rarely if ever questions the premise of the radical movement (hence latter-day conservatives and neocons will find much to disagree with). Nonetheless
column25: it's quite a text--nah
column26: screw the academic jargon
column27: it's a good story
column28: and it's worth your time

column1: Valian is a cognitive psychologist.  I saw her speak at a local university and was impressed by the breadth of evidence she presented re: how ingrained gender discrimination is in the thinking of both men and women
column2: but also with her logical suggestions for addressing this problem.  (She
column3: as a matter of fact
column4: was invited by women students and faculty to help them strategize how to get more women into higher positions.)  In her convincing talk
column5: I was struck by the evidence that discrimination is not something "done" by men to keep women down
column6: but is
column7: in fact
column8: "done" equally to women by both men and women.   So I got her book and was more impressed when I read it.  Valian presents experiment after experiment showing that women are held back by psychologically ingrained ideas held by both men AND women.  She calls these gender schemas
column9: which are a way for the brain to organize complex information.  (They are close to stereotypes
column10: but schema is a more neutral term).  The evidence is fascinating and convincing.  Examples: if a man and a woman of identical height stand in an identical height door frame
column11: viewed separately and then rated
column12: both men and women perceive the man to be taller.  Or how a woman can make a suggestion during a meeting and no one hears it
column13: but later a man makes the exact same suggestion and everyone hears it and thinks it's great.  (Example after example you will all recognize and be disgusted by!)  While the knowledge presented in this book is depressing
column14: Valian ends with suggestions for ways to become aware of these fallacies in thinking and then actively counteract them within organizations.  I LOVE this book and it is a true eye-opener.  It has really opened my eyes to what women have to surmount to get ahead when there are so many hidden negative assumptions ingrained in our culture.  While it is written in an academic style and perhaps less accessible than a pop-psychology type or journalist-written book
column15: one could read the introduction and conclusions to the chapters and skim parts of the in between text if it gets too heavy.  (Like all academic writers she says her main points in the chapter intro
column16: then presents evidence
column17: then summarizes at the end of the chapters.)  I highly recommend this book!

column5: blows apart that myth.  He says that slavery had great variety
column6: based on geographic
column7: economic and generational factors. The first generation of slaves in America were creoles
column8: born of white and African American parents.  They frequently lived along the sea and interacted with people of all walks of life
column9: were traders and often spoke multiple languages.  These slaves frequently stayed with their families
column10: knew and utilized the courts to petition for freedom
column11: they worked with their slave-owners to grow crops and to negotiate payment for their eventual freedom.   This changed with subsequent generations who were plucked from central Africa and did not have the same experience with the white world.  While slaves in these subsequent generations lost the power to negotiate the terms of their slavery with their slaveholders
column12: they were able to grab autonomy in other ways.  They grew and sold goods in cities
column13: they purchased their freedom
column14: though often at a high price.  They escaped and formed maroon armed communities.  A few other factors also played a significant role in determining the virulence of slavery
column15: specifically geography and economics.   Some crops like cotton and tobacco were  well suited to the plantation systems and in areas where those crops grew well
column16: the slave system was particularly harsh.  History was another factor. In the form of the American Revolution it disrupted the plantation system
column17: because the plantation owners
column18: who were often patriots with strong beliefs in the rights of man
column19: also owned slaves and defended their right to do so.  The loyalists took advantage of this dilemma and often had the plantation slaves fighting on the loyalist side in exchange for the promise of becoming free men.  Sometimes they even delivered on that promise.   My only criticism is that I wanted more of a narrative that would bring together the various aspects of slavery.  I was left with the feeling that American slavery was really Mississippi slavery or South Carolina slavery or New York slavery.   The legacy of slavery appears to be monolithic even if the experience of slavery was not.

I found this book to be very helpful in understanding Kant's aesthetics.  Kant's philosophy is notoriously difficult - so it is nice to have access to books such as this one
column2: that interpret Kant's writing in a non-technical way for a contemporary audience.  The book analyzes the overall argument of the Critique of Aesthetic Judgment (the first part of the Critique of Judgment) in a clear
column3: conversational
column4: and questioning style that is appropriate for beginners and more advanced readers of Kant.  The author skillfully uses possible objections and apparent ambiguities in Kant's text as a way of delving more deeply into the substance of what Kant is saying.  The author states in the preface that the book does not presuppose prior knowledge of Kant's writings
column5: and I found this to be true on the whole.  The book does indeed point out many connections between Kant's aesthetics and the epistemology of Kant's Critique of Pure Reason.  There is extensive discussion of the four "moments" of the judgment of taste
column6: as well as sections on genius
column7: the sublime
column8: the connection between morality and the beautiful
column9: and the question of whether there can be genius in mathematics.  Several extra features make this book stand out from other introductory works on Kant.  First
column10: technical terms are highlighted in bold in the text and defined in the extensive glossary at the end of the book.  Second
column11: at the end of each chapter subsection there is an annotated list of some of the secondary literature that addresses that particular topic.  Third
column12: at the end of the book there is a summary and overview of the main points of the book

column1: So begins the introduction to this singular and essential book about the Japanese aesthetic of wabi-sabi. Long associated with the Japanese tea ceremony

column4: to the mood and spatial qualities of tea huts and the gardens that contain them.  Leonard Koren engages us with his views as an artist informed by many years of living with and observing all things Japanese. column5: the binding

column7: architecture and gardens
column8: but have never been able to quite put their finger on the underlying aesthetic
column9: this book creates a context for understanding and further discovery

column7: until I received the DVD.   The thrust of the story is that the dapper and elegant Cosmo Topper (Leo G. Carroll) is vice-president of a bank. He is married to the sweet but dim Henrietta (Lee Patrick). They live in a house that they bought from the estate of an unfortunate young couple
column8: George and Marion Kirby (Robert Sterling and Anne Jeffreys)
column9: who died in a skiing accident after being swept away by an avalanche. Their St. Bernard
column10: Neil
column11: who was unable to rescue them
column12: also died with them. To Cosmo's surprise
column13: his house is haunted by their ghosts and that of their alcohol imbibing St. Bernard. The problem is that only he can see or hear them. This allows for a lot of funny episodes

column18: and Robert Sterling is great as her freewheeling husband. Of course
column19: our cocktail loving St. Bernard is wonderfully portrayed by Buck. Moreover

column21: which certainly takes the viewer on a trip down memory lane and provides its own share of laughs. I only wish that some television honcho would consider a remake of this wonderful television series.

column1: The other day a teacher came into the library where I work and explained to me that she was doing a unit with her kids on quilting.  She already had some non-fiction titles on the subject
column2: but what she really wanted was picture books that talked about the craft.  Immediately I thought of "Show Way" by Jacqueline Woodson
column3: "Goha the Wise Fool"
column4: by Denys Johnson-Davies (a quilted picture book)
column5: "Oma's Quilt" by Paulette Bourgeois
column6: "Tar Beach" by Faith Ringgold (another quilted picture book)
column7: and "Sweet Clara and the Freedom Quilt" by Deborah Hopkinson.  But even before any of these book jumped to my mind
column8: before I'd even stopped to consider a one of them
column9: there was a book that I thought of first.  "The Patchwork Quilt" by Valerie Flournoy is (I would dare say) the best-known quilting picture book of them all.  A winner of the Coretta Scott King Award and the very first winner of the prestigious Ezra Jack Keats Books Award
column10: this 1985 production and Reading Rainbow Book has remained a classic well past the time when most book lie on shelves forgotten.   	 Grandma has an idea.  When she was a little girl her own mother made her a beautiful patchwork quilt.  Now Tanya
column11: her granddaughter
column12: is showing some interest in Grandma's quilting.  Therefore
column13: she's going to make a quilt of her own.  A "masterpiece" is what it's going to be.  So when any family member has a special outfit made or has to get rid of a beloved set of pants
column14: Grandma's always there
column15: handy with the scissors.  Slowly everyone in the family gets his or herself added to the quilt
column16: until one day Grandma gets sick.  There her quilt sits on the back of her old chair
column17: gathering dust.  Fortunately
column18: Tanya knows she can take charge.  Her mother agrees to do the sewing and Tanya cuts fabric.  Even her brothers get in on the act.  Soon enough Grandma is well again
column19: the quilt is finished
column20: and everyone is now a part of it.   	 Flournoy has written a book that has a great deal of dignity to it.  The words are not necessarily easy ones
column21: but they come off as natural when written on the page.  Flournoy sets up emotional plot points
column22: like Tanya's mother coming to accept why the quilt is really important.  Grandma's recovery
column23: I should point out
column24: isn't presented as something miraculous or out of place.  It works within the framework of the narrative.  There's really only one moment in the plot that gave me pause.  When Tanya starts working on the quilt herself
column25: she feels that there's a piece that's definitely missing.  She ponders and ponders this until finally she realizes what that piece might be.  Grandma.  Grandma is missing from the quilt.  So while Grandma is asleep Tanya sneaks into her room
column26: goes to the old patchwork quilt under which her grandmother sleeps
column27: and then proceeds to cut it up without asking anyone for permission.  I don't know about you
column28: but if I woke up and found that my quilt had been lovingly vandalized in this way I might get a little bit tetchy.  Tanya never gets in trouble for it since her motives were pure.  Still
column29: it's an odd little addition.  I mean
column30: couldn't she at least have asked permission?  	 Jerry Pinkey
column31: artist extraordinaire
column32: was the man responsible for the illustrations.  I'm not a huge fan of his work
column33: but he does a lovely job with this book.  The quilt looks very real.  My grandmother made me one back that was very similar to the one presented on the cover.  I'll admit right here and now that since this book was written in 1985
column34: it's swimming in nostalgia for me.  I love the 80s hair and clothes that people wear in it.  From Grandma's gigantic glasses to Mama's shirt/vest combinations and shoulder pads
column35: children of the eightiese will find themselves swimming in memories.  Remember polo shirts that had collars that were different colors from the fabric of the shirt themselves?  Remember shirts that had ruffles for no particular reason at all?  It's all here.  But for kids
column36: this won't serve as a distraction since they won't recognize the era.  Plus
column37: Pinkney cleverly  included some dated elements
column38: but not a lot.  If I didn't point out to you that it was written over 20 years ago
column39: you might never notice it yourself. 	 The children who grew up with this book are having kids of their own these days.  I dare say that for some
column40: "The Patchwork Quilt" will be the first title they purchase for their children and the children of their friends.  Arresting and emotional without playing those same emotions for cheap
column41: Florunoy's book is her best known work.  If you should be particularly fond of it
column42: be sure to check out its sequel
column43: "Tanya's Reunion"
column44: written ten years later.  A necessary read

column1: I was a little tentative to order the iTrip LCD because of some of the bad reviews I read.  It seems like there are very few people sitting on the fence with this item. column2: it was in my mailbox the day before I left.  I unwrapped it and went out to the vehicle to test it.    I plugged it into my 20GB iPod photo and right off the bat thought I had trouble.  It wouldn't power up
column3: I tried plugging and unplugging
column4: cleaning the contacts and finally as a last resort
column5: read the instructions.  After plugging it in you have to play the song before it will power on.  This immediately explains why so many poeple complain of DOAs right out of the box.    I set the frequency to the lowest available on the FM band and presto!!! instant music.  I don't live in an extremely populated area so I can't really comment on other stations bleeding through but loud passages are loud and quiet passages are quiet.    Many reviewers complained of bad sound quality but you must remember this.  It doesn't matter how great the quality of the song is on your iPod
column6: you are playing it over FM radio so it will never sound better than FM radio.    I inherited my father's '91 Accord work car when he retired and it has a bare bones AM/FM radio with a tone control(bass AND treble all rolled into one handy knob!!!) and cheap 6 1/2 inch speakers in the front doors.  When I drive I like to listen to talk radio and podcasts and occasionally music.  The sound quality was exactly what I expected

The bass still thumped and the highs seemed just a tiny bit off but still not bad at all.  I am completely satisfied with the product.    One strange thing that I noticed that may explain why some people complain of bad sound quality is if you tap on the iTrip
column8: the sound comes through your speakers much like tapping on a microphone.  If you were to lay it on a hard surface in your vehicle you could probably hear it through your speakers when encountering rough road.    Unless there was a defective batch sent out
column9: I don't know where all of the complaints come from.  I got mine for $15 from a private seller on Amazon and consider it a great purchase especially for that amount of money. Don't hesitate to buy one
column10: it works as advertised and the sound quality is what it is.  If you keep these things in mind
column11: you won't be disappointed

column1: Hawaii is one of the most beautiful
column2: bittersweet movies ever made. From the opening prologue with Keoki (Manu Tupou) relating the history of the Hawaiian people over the glorious music of Elmer Bernstein I knew I was going to love this movie.   Keoki
column3: a native Hawaiian and first convert to the Christian faith has traveled across the ocean to America in hopes of convincing some of the upcoming graduates of a Calvinist College in New England to sail to Hawaii and share their faith with his people.  Amongst those to accept the challenge is Abner Hale (Max Von Sydow) a young man of good intentions
column4: but overzealous and prideful in his Christianity. Unable to join in the missionary effort unless he is married
column5: one is arranged for him with the lovely Jerusha Bromley (Julie Andrews).  The hardships of the sea voyage are only a taste of the hardship that face them once they arrive at their destination. As the new arrivals acclimate themselves to their new surroundings Jerusha soon falls in love with the open and loving nature to the natives while Abner grows more narrow and unbending in his proselytization efforts. Unable to appreciate the beauty around him
column6: he sees only heathens doomed to hell for their pagan ways.  Abner eventually loses sight of the Christian message to "love one another" and in a fit of range calls upon God to bring death and destruction to the unrepentant Hawaiians. When a measles epidemic spreads through the islands it appears Abner prayer has been answered with dire consequences.    A poignant and ultimately sad tale of the lose of yet another native 'land of paradise' brought about the greed and lack of concern by foreign powers.   MGM only receives -4 Stars- on this DVD. Why in the world they didn't restore 'Hawaii' to its full 189 minutes theatrical version instead of releasing this truncated 161 minute version is beyond me. Come on MGM

column9: Django was only verbally reticent. Musically
column10: he is one of the most articulate

column19: superfast playing.  In the endnotes are many mentions of "interview with author

column1: This work takes giant steps with the history of science and cosmology. From the Big Bang to Life
column2: from Copernicus to Lovelock
column3: Professor Gribbin advances the theory of complex order from simple rules.   A reader familiar with complexity theory may feel they have heard all this before. Professor Gribbin however takes a very mathematical approach to the subject and delivers am interesting and readable account of his subject.    I recommend this work to serious lay readers (casual science readers may find the math daunting
column4: although just appreciating the author's enthusiasm will be infectious) and to a general academic audience. The scope is vast but engagingly presented and readable.  Throughout the work Professor Gribbin goes on tangents and then announces that it is out of the scope of the present work. I challenge the good professor to write a new work on just those tangents. I for one will be happy to read it.

column1: This book is a good introduction to 1 e4 Nf6 whether you play it with White or Black.    The author has some recommendations about how to play it.  With White
column2: he advises the main line (1 e4 Nf6 2 e5 Nd5 3 d4 d6 4 Nf3)
column3: and he gives advice on how to play it solidly or tactically and theoretically.   I figured this book wouldn't help me with White
column4: since I play 2 Nc3.  But Cox does give a game that goes 1 e4 Nf6 2 Nc3 d5 3 e5 Ne4 4 Nce2 d4 5 c3.  That's a good line for White
column5: and Black would be better off with 2...e5
column6: letting White choose between a Vienna and a Four Knights.  Now
column7: what about the Alekhine with Black?  You may say you don't play it!  But what if you get in a blindfold game
column8: and your opponent plays 1 d4 Nf6 2 e5 (only now do you discover that White's first move was 1 e4).  Or maybe you are in a 5-minute game and you want to have some fun with Black and not play your main defence.  The author boasts that you can be prepared to meet 1 e4 in 30 minutes.  Against the main line
column9: you can try 4...dxe5 5 Nxe5 c6.  Against 1 e4 Nf6 2 e5 Nd5 3 d4 d6 4 c4
column10: you play 4...Nb6 5 f4 (if 5 exd6 exd6) dxe5 6 fxe5 c5 7 d5 g6.  Against 1 e4 Nf6 2 e5 Nd5 3 c4 Nb6 4 c5 Nd5 5 Nc3
column11: you play 5...c6
column12: intending to follow this up with ...e6 and ...b6.  If White plays 1 e4 Nf6 2 e5 Nd5 3 Nc3
column13: you play 3...Nxc3 and 4...d5.  And if White avoids the Alekhine with 1 e4 Nf6 2 Nc3
column14: you play 2...e5
column15: settling for that Vienna game.  The author also gives recommendations for positional and tactical repertoires for Black.  Years ago
column16: I tried playing the Alekhine in four games.  Two opponents played the main line.  I tried 4...dxe5 5 Nxe5 g6 (which Cox devotes two games to).  The first time I saw this
column17: I continued as Cox recommends
column18: with 6 Bc4 c6.  But I soon got in trouble.  In the other game
column19: I answered 6 Bc4 with 6...Be6.  It's not in this book
column20: but I think it's a good choice.  My other two opponents tried 1 d4 Nf6 2 e5 Nd5 3 Nc3 Nxc3 4 dxc3 d6.  Now I expected 5 Bc4.  I intended to reply 5...Nc6 (not 5...dxe5?? 6 Bxf7
column21: losing the Black Queen) 6 Nf3 dxe5 7 Qxd8+
column22: which is acceptable for Black.  But instead
column23: one opponent tried 5 Bf4 dxe5 6 Qxd8+ Kxd8 7 0-0-0+ Bd7 8 Bxe5 f6 9 Bg3 e5
column24: after which I was okay.  The other came up with 5 Nf3 dxe5 6 Qxd8+ Kxd8 7 Nxe5 Ke8
column25: which led to a tough fight.    This book is up-to-date and easy to read.  I recommend it.

column1: This book provides everything you ever wanted to know about the Chabad movement and more. Fishkoff
column2: an American Jewish journalist who is not Orthodox
column3: was granted a remarkable amount of entree into  the Chabad community and took full advantage of it. This is a sympathetic portrait
column4: though not an unquestioning one.  As a reasonably knowledgeable Jew and a former journalist myself
column5: I found that Fishkoff answered all the questions I had about Chabad. For example: Where do the "shlichim" (emissaries) get all their money from? (Answer: they have to fund-raise for themselves. They only receive moral support and educational materials from Chabad central headquarters.)   Notably
column6: Fishkoff directly addresses the more controversial aspects of Chabad. She discusses their extraordinarily interesting relationships with Conservative and Reform Jews. Briefly
column7: Chabad welcomes less-observant Jews and does not demand that they adopt Hasidic or Orthodox practices; it officially denies recognition to non-Orthodox synagogues and rabbis
column8: but often creates de facto alliances with them "on the ground."  Fishkoff also addresses the controversy over messianism that continues to divide the Chabad movement. She is perhaps more optimistic than some other observers that support will soon die down for the view that the late Lubavitcher rebbe
column9: who died in 1994
column10: was the Messiah. She also gives a full account of the Chabad movement's concerted efforts to place Chanukah menorahs in public places -- and the court battles this has engendered
column11: which often place Chabad on the opposite side of civil liberties groups and of many other Jewish organizations

column1: In his most readable book
column2: Shepard lays out his thesis that the fundamental nature of humans was formed by our hundreds of thousands of years as hunter gatherers
column3: and that our subsequent lives as nomadic  pastoralists or settled agriculturalists have been very destructive not  only of our surroundings but of our psyches.  The problems created by these  last two ways of life have been described by other authors (e.g.
column4: Jared  Diamond
column5: in The Third Chimpanzee)
column6: but Shepard's  treatment is rich and  impressive.  Shepard's language is
column7: in fact
column8: often beautiful
column9: although it  is not easy
column10: principally because of vocabulary.  This book was the last of  four read by the students in my freshman Human Evolution class this past  term.  About 3/4 of them found it fairly difficult going
column11: but many also  found it very rewarding--in fact it deeply affected several.  I thought the  book's weaknesses were (1) its lack of well-developed ideas about how to  reconnect with our Pleistocene heritage
column12: given that we are now stuck with  agriculture (and industrialism
column13: etc.)--Shepard presents a long list of  possibilities in the last chapter
column14: but many are very unrealistic (and he  does not include the learning and practicing of "primitive"  technologies
column15: such as making fire by friction
column16: making stone tools
column17: braintanning hides
column18: and so on--a powerful
column19: deeply satisfying way to  understand our common past)
column20: and (2) his near failure to acknowledge that  agriculture can be practiced well
column21: that it need not be destructive
column22: and  that it can give one a strong and healthy connection to the land.  (Shepard  in a chapter endnote does praise Wendell Berry
column23: Wes Jackson
column24: and Gary  Snyder for their sort of farming.) These problems are
column25: however
column26: minor; this  is an important book
column27: and should be read by any interested in human  evolution

column1: In Lasting Leadership
column2: we identify eight attributes or qualities that have enabled the 25 individuals (Of the 25 leaders profiled in this book
column3: two have died  Sam Walton in 1992 and Mary Kay Ash in 2001. We were able to get interviews with 15 of the other 23
column4: including Jeff Bezos
column5: John Bogle
column6: James Burke
column7: Michael Dell
column8: William George
column9: Louis Gerstner
column10: Lee Iacocca
column11: Herb Kelleher
column12: Andrew Grove
column13: Peter Lynch
column14: Charles Schwab
column15: Fred Smith
column16: Ted Turner
column17: Jack Welch
column18: and Muhammad Yunus
column19: in addition to Mary Kay Ashs son
column20: Richard Rogers) to overcome major challenges as well as to nurture their own leadership styles. These attributes  each of which has its own chapter in the book  include   	Building a strong corporate culture  	Truth telling  	Finding and catering to under-served markets  	Seeing the invisible  that is
column21: spotting potential winners or faint trends before their rivals or customers do  	Using price to build competitive advantage  	Managing and building their organizations brand (which
column22: in some cases
column23: may be their own name)  	Being fast learners  	Managing risk  None of the leaders in this book has all these attributes. If that were a requirement of lasting leadership
column24: the world would have no leaders at all. At the same time
column25: one attribute alone is not enough to ensure long-lived leadership. A leader with a single attribute may succeed briefly
column26: but the success will not be sustained unless other qualities exist to keep the momentum going (from the Introduction).   In this context
column27: to explore the theme of lasting leadership
column28: Mukul Pandya and Robbie Shell divide this invaluable handbook into ten chapters. Each of the chapters from one to nine takes a close look at 25 leaders approach to leadership.   Finally
column29: in the last chapter  conclusion
column30: Pandya and Shell say that the lives of the 25 leaders covered in these pages are instructive because of the choices they made  often in the face of adversity  on their way to defining success in their respective fields. Their experiences suggest questions worth considering when assessing the leadership potential of ourselves or others:  	Do we seek the positive seam when confronted with circumstances?  	How do we cultivate a corporate culture that inspires and empowers those around us?  	How do we emphasize the importance of honesty
column31: especially at times when honesty is not the easiest course to pursue?  	Have we sought to identify and cultivate underserved markets?  	Can we see the invisible? Are we able to dig deeper and understand the connections between seemingly unrelated phenomena?  	Do we understand the role of price as a potential competitive advantage in our particular industry?  	Do we cultivate and maximize brand identity?  	Are we fast learners
column32: able to make decisions quickly and reserve position when necessary?  	How well do we manage risk? (pp.240-241)  Strongly recommended

 There's a saying among statisticians (a group I identify with from time to time): You can always draw a straight line with two points."  Loosely translated
column4: this means that you should avoid drawing conclusions based on fewer than 3 observations.  This being my third Brother Cadfael mystery (I obtained a random selection from a neighbor's giveaway bin)
column5: I feel I can now opine more confidently
column6: knowing that my recommendations are probably not based on a coincidental selection of the best the author has to offer.  As always

column8: with particular focus on monastery life.  This installment
column9: however
column10: is less of a whodunit than the others.  The principal crime was committed hundreds of miles away from Cadfael's home in Shrewsbury and all he has to go on are some second or third-hand accounts and some unusual visitors at the annual pilgrimage in honor of St. Winifred.  In some ways
column11: the mystery solves itself

column13: there is an especially potent dose of it here
column14: as the brewing civil war between Empress Maud and King Stephen comes to a head.  Wading through these details makes this a bit more difficult of a read than usual.  One interesting upshot of this part of the story is the implication that it is possible for political (if not military) enemies to be civil and gentlemanly with each other.  What a novel concept!  The book also explores the nature of revenge
column15: and the ultimate lack of fulfillment in it.  This
column16: too
column17: is a concept that is mostly foreign in today's world.  Romance is again a significant feature
column18: always a pleasant surprise given that the setting is a monastery.  In this case
column19: however
column20: the romance is relatively conventional and only peripherally related to the crime.  It does however
column21: provide useful clues for resolving the mystery.  Another subplot relates to a mysterious visitor whose past is connected with Cadfael's
column22: resulting in a surprise revelation at the end of the book.  Cadfael also engages in a good deal of introspection regarding miraculous divine intervention
column23: as befitting the occasion of the pilgrimage.  In summary
column24: this book continues the tradition of solid storytelling and fascinating reading established by the author in the Brother Cadfael series.  Both novitiates and long-time fans of the series will enjoy this book

column1: Vandana Shiva has become one of the most outspoken defenders of biodiversity and the commons
column2: persistently working to advance the public understanding of a complicated history of corporate and legislative decisions that have changed the landscape of our lives and the lives of people the world over.  She has contributed to a vital dialogue about the effects of globalization and the silent tragedies that are occuring every day because of strange business practices and the relentless politics of the new manifest destiny.  "Biopiracy: The Plunder of Nature and Knowledge" is a succinct and accessible introduction to the issue of patents and corporate control of the natural world.  Shiva is an articulate educator who writes about the difficult and often unspoken history of corporate exploitation of the knowledge of non-Western cultures.  By arguing vehemently for the preservation of the farmer's right to save seeds
column3: as well as local rights to ecological and historically tested uses of the natural world

column1: Edward Abbey's novels displayed his Sagebrush-style conservationist ideals
column2: and his near-Anarchist sentiments took greatest root here. This is a near-future dystopia tale in which a thinly described economic disaster has forced most people to flee Abbey's beloved desert southwest
column3: leaving just a few hardy naturalist survivors trying to create a non-government lifestyle. Meanwhile the wasted city of Phoenix becomes the base for a big-thinking ex-military man who wants to take control of all of humanity and eliminate dissenters who stand in his way. This novel is overflowing with excellent and thought-provoking political philosophy
column4: especially when it comes to the exact meaning of "freedom" and how that term is actually defined by whoever has power. Unfortunately
column5: this book's politics may be a little outdated
column6: because nowadays I suspect that a western power-hungry demagogue would be the exact ideological opposite of Abbey's villain here (this guy's a socialist). The novel has a few other problems
column7: such as longwinded and tiresome monologues from the characters. Most of the action is rather predictable chase scenes
column8: and the story is capped off by an inconclusive ending
column9: which cries out for a sequel that never appeared. This is a very hard-hitting and thought-provoking novel
column10: but Abbey's basic ideas are better defined elsewhere. [~doomsdayer520~

column1: Francis Fukuyama writes what probably is the clearest prose of any economist since Adam Smith. In this book he provides a fascinating and
column2: I think
column3: accurate anatomy of the origins and principles of neo-conservative thinking. He then uses a neo-conservative perspective to examine such controversial and contentious subjects as the Second Iraqi War and its aftermath
column4: U.S. Foreign Policy in the 21st Century
column5: and the effect of Globalization on the relations of states. In the course of doing this he provides a devastating critique of the current administration's strategic doctrine of preventive war as described in both the National Security Strategy of the United States (NSS) of 2002 and 2006. He points out that preemptive war is vastly different from preventive war and that while the former makes a good deal of sense the latter does not. Fukuyama makes clear that the real U.S. goal of the Second Iraqi War namely to bring about a regime change in Iraq is in accordance with neo-conservative thinking that the nature of regimes do mater. His opposition to the war is based first on his belief that the U.S. initiated the war as a preventive war without a clear understanding of the enemy and second on his neo-conservative distrust of ambitious social engineering projects either in the U.S. or abroad. Less noticed in the uproar over his opposition to the war
column6: is his rather effective argument that the UN confirms the neo-conservative distrust of international institutions and law. He believes
column7: and offers some sound arguments to support this belief
column8: that the UN is largely ineffectual and marginalized by 21st Century Globalization. This book may not make anyone want to become a neo-conservative
column9: but I think it will cause many to recognize that the principles guiding neo-conservatives are not quite as lunatic as the current administration makes them appear. This is a good book full of interesting ideas that are well presented.

column1: When I first went shopping for a second controller for my GameCube
column2: I admit I was looking for one that matched my Platinum Edition controller. I couldn't find one that wasn't a Wavebird (nothing wrong with a Wavebird - the wireless controller - that I know of

column4: buying a different controller was a smart thing to do. Why didn't I plan on that in the first place? I spent part of the winter battling a cold or the flu at various times
column5: and I can't underestimate the importance of controlling the spread of viruses and bacteria. When a housemate or friend wants to play GameCube as I lay suffering on the other couch
column6: I am able to croak out the words "use the black one today. Trust me."  I also have a phobia against third-party hardware - so it's good of Nintendo (not to mention profitable for Nintendo) to sell spare parts.  The most important things about a controller are: does it fit comfortably in your hand
column7: and are the buttons easy to find and use? The only thing I don't like is the placement of the Z button. The cord is plenty long
column8: and the buttons are responsive enough. I also like that they're color-coded

column1: This book contains translated fascicles from Dogen Zenji's Shobogenzo
column2: a massive and inscrutable philosophical work regarding the nature of life and reality.    Within are some of the most popular
column3: influential
column4: and profound selections of the Shobogenzo regarding zazen meditation practice
column5: which can be everything from somewhat confusing to utterly nonsensical to anyone without a store of background knowledge in Zen Buddhism.    As a consequence
column6: this book is best geared towards those who already have a significant understanding of the language and style of Zen.  It is definitely not for someone who has never encountered Buddhist or Zen thought before.    That said
column7: Dogen Zenji's philosophy is unsurpassed in its depth and influence in Japanese Zen and
column8: to a large extent
column9: Western Zen as well.  The Shobogenzo
column10: written in the 1200's
column11: is still studied and revered today as one of the most brilliant works ever written regarding Buddhist philosophy and practice.  Many Zen teachers have dedicated themselves exclusively to Dogen's thought.  This book
column12: though it does not contain other seminal fascicles such as the Genjokoan
column13: is a great resource to anyone interested in reading not second-hand explanations
column14: but selected translations from one of the most famous teachers and reformers of Zen Buddhism

column1: What can be scarier than being stuck Alone In The Dark with Martin Landau and Jack Palance?  This film attempts to answer that question and does a fine job.  I'm a huge nut for any B horror picture
column2: and it's nice sometimes to actually see some real star power in them.  Granted
column3: Landau and Palance weren't at the highest point in their careers when they did this.  The film has Dwight Schultz
column4: who you may remember as Murdock in the A-Team
column5: as a new therapist at an asylum run by Psychiatrist
column6: Donald Pleasance(who smokes pot in his office).  "The men on the 3rd floor" are the extremely dangerous lunatics who decide to kill Murdock coz they believe he has murdered their former therapist.  There are 4 central killers-First is Marin Landau as "Preacher"
column7: a bible quoting psycho.  He's fantastic in this part.  Palance is the paranoid Vietnam vet named Hawkes
column8: who is basically the ringleader.  He doesn't have alot of lines
column9: but since it's Jack Palance
column10: he's wonderfully creepy and convincing.  The third is played by Erland van Lidth as a child molester who is childlike himself.  You may remember Erland as the opera singing Roman Stalker in The Running Man("Cut! Cut! Go to commercial!!").  The fourth is rarely seen and this makes him interesting.  Since his face is always off camera
column11: a name actor isn't necessary.  He's called The Bleeder
column12: and comes off as the most dangerous of the 4 coz he doesn't speak and at one point pre-dates Jason Voorhees by wearing a hockey mask.  Donald Pleasance is awfully nutty and funny in his role of the doctor.  In fact
column13: you start to wonder if he's actually a mental patient himself.  Schultz is decent as the straight man
column14: a far cry from his Murdock character.  This film starts and builds up wonderfully.  It has a fantastic buildup to the point where it becomes like Night Of The Living Dead with Schultz and his family trapped inside their home during a blackout with the band of crazies outside.  Unfortunately the film falls kinda flat here.  With such a good buildup and collection of characters
column15: you expect alot more out of this confrontation than you get.  It's actually kinda boring and not very intense at all.  Despite this shortcoming
column16: the film is well worth watching for the performances.

column1: The nations of Europe have been homes to various wars for centuries
column2: until a bunch of the countries got together after the Second World War to create a common economic market
column3: and perhaps prevent any more of these conflicts. It created a form of European identity that has now become the European Union. But the *idea* of Europe
column4: a unified area of diverse cultures that nevertheless falls under the rule of one authority
column5: can be traced back to Charlemagne
column6: the Frankish emperor of the late 8th and early 9th centuries. In his new book
column7: Charlemagne
column8: Derek Wilson examines the emperor's life
column9: but he also examines the myth of Charlemagne through the ages. He looks at how subsequent rulers have used the Charlemagne for their own ends
column10: and how his attempts to conquer and hold together as much of Europe as possible
column11: to have one Europe
column12: has been a precursor to what we have now. Many rulers have tried to duplicate his achievements
column13: but none of them have done so as completely
column14: or perhaps as fairly
column15: as Charlemagne did
column16: even if it was done through conquest.   Charlemagne is a fairly short book
column17: but it does pack a lot of information into it. Wilson begins by giving a short history of Europe up until the time of Charlemagne's birth
column18: including an interesting set of maps
column19: one of which is the European Economic Community in 1957 and one that is the extent of Charlemagne's empire in 814. The two look very similar
column20: with only the southern part of Italy not being included in Charlemagne's area. Food for thought
column21: but Wilson goes on to say that
column22: while Charlemagne's story demonstrates this desire for unity
column23: it is basically a story
column24: full of military actions
column25: barbarian invasions
column26: and political/religious intrigue. His father and grandfather began all of this
column27: but it was Charlemagne's force of personality that really made it work. This introduction is a good one
column28: setting the scene in a very interesting manner but never losing sight of the fact that many stories have been added to Charlemagne's over the years to support what somebody wants to do. The whole thing is a story
column29: and we don't have a lot of primary sources about his life. Those we do have could very well be biased
column30: as the most prominent biography of the time was written during the reign of one of Charlemagne's sons
column31: and it really makes the son look good. Contemporary biographies seem to gloss over military defeats
column32: with scarcely a mention of the disastrous foray into Moslem Spain
column33: for example.   What's even more interesting is that a full third of the book doesn't talk about Charlemagne himself
column34: but about how his image has carried on through the years since his death. We see the beginnings of it as the Empire falls apart shortly after his death
column35: as his sons just don't have the forcefulness that their father had. The Empire does survive through one of his son's reign
column36: but it doesn't survive for long. Wilson uses this to show how much the idea of Europe was a personal thing at the time
column37: with the various warring factions that were under one umbrella starting to feel the chafe as Charlemagne's personal influence waned with his death. Wilson then proceeds to give us a brief history of Europe up to the modern day
column38: placing the legend of Charlemagne within that context
column39: from the rise of the Holy Roman Empire through the years until its final death. Wilson details the fall of remains of the Holy Roman Empire in 1806
column40: after a long period where it survived basically in name only
column41: as well as how Napoleon (and even Hitler) used the legend of Charlemagne to further their own ends. I found this part of the book fascinating as I was fairly unfamiliar with him and his influence
column42: despite knowing the basics about him being the first emperor of western Europe. One interesting bit of history that I did not know is that Charlemagne divided his empire into three pieces for his three sons. One basically takes the shape of France
column43: one the shape of Germany (at least western Germany)
column44: and there's a piece in the middle that encompasses the land which Germany and France have been fighting over for centuries.   It's intriguing things like this which makes Charlemagne a great read. Wilson does a deft job giving us Charlemagne's history too
column45: both of the man as he's growing up and becoming king
column46: how he wrests control of the entirety of his father's kingdom from his brother
column47: as well as his time as Emperor
column48: when Pope Leo III crowned him (though the details of this crowning
column49: as well as the impetus for it
column50: remain obscured by history) Emperor of the West and as he expanded his lands. Wilson gives us as much detail as probably exists about Charlemagne's life and times
column51: emphasizing how religious he was and how learned (he could read
column52: but he couldn't write
column53: and he loved scholarly discussions to be carried out over dinner). He doesn't gloss over the bad parts
column54: however
column55: even saying that
column56: in modern times
column57: Charlemagne would be considered a tyrant. But he points out that many of the cultural traditions in the lands that he conquered were allowed to remain
column58: though he admits this perhaps was because of the difficulty in governing far-away provinces.   What I found most interesting and well-presented about this section
column59: however
column60: is how Wilson gives us a sense of the time around Charlemagne. The political struggles between the two remaining parts of the Roman Empire
column61: as well as the religious ones (even giving a brief accounting of the controversy in Constantinople over the use of iconography in Christian practices) were simply fascinating. This
column62: combined with the examination of Charlemagne's legacy (as well as his legend) makes Charlemagne a wonderful read for anybody interested in the history of the Middle Ages. It may even be of interest to those looking for the history of European unity. It all started right here
column63: even if it was by the sword. And the idea
column65: has never truly died.  David Ro

column1: Robert Louis Stevenson (1850 - 1894) was a remarkable author from the Victorian Era. He has left us at least two masterpieces: "The Treasure Island" (1883) and "The Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde" (1886) and some other good novels such as "The Black Arrow" (1888).  It is amazing how writers and poets are able
column2: thru intuition
column3: to anticipate events or discoveries. When this book was first published
column4: Sigmund Freud was studying with Charcot and not so many years later will produce his theoretic corpus of the human psyche. At some points the present story touches Freud's conceptualizations.   Dr. Jekyll suspect evil burdens every human soul
column5: being an obstacle in its way to goodness. So he investigates and produces a drug that "liberates" the evil spirit and doing so he intend to be relived of it. But Evil starts to grow each time more powerful and Mr. Hyde end cornering Dr. Jekyll into impotence and fear.  This story has captivated the public's imagination for more than a hundred years. Movies
column6: comics and theater pieces had evolved from it. His tortured dual character is now a well known icon as Stoker's Dracula or Mary Shelley's Frankenstein. Even if you know more or less the story and its ending
column7: reading this very short book is a powerful adventure. A Classic you shouldn't let pass by unheeded!  Reviewed by Max Yofre.

column1: I had taken up karate with my son

I'm looking forward to getting my black belt and joining my son in black belt classes in the not too distant future.

column1: Standing in the shadow of an established genius can be a difficult thing. Even more
column2: coming into contact with someone that expects you to measure up to or even surpass said genius can also be difficult if not daunting. While specific examples of this motif escape me right now
column3: it has been used countless times in literature and film to produce some incredibly memorable characters and storylines. And it's justifiably so: in some ways
column4: standing in the shadow of the established sort of dooms the reception of some works by default. (In my opinion
column5: the most recent and glaring of this would be Neutral Milk Hotel's excellent On Avery Island.) However
column6: sometimes it is wise to forget that the established exists to judge the music on its own merits. Other times
column7: however
column8: the two can be compared to reveal that the subordinate has its own eccentricities/traits that sets it completely apart for its "big cousin
column9: if you will. I shall be going the comparative route.   De Capo's big brother" is obviously Love's widely acclaimed magnum opus Forever Changes. It's known for utilizing grandiose Sgt. Pepperesque orchestration to accompany and ultimately illuminate Lee's tender orchestrations. However
column10: to many modern ears that I encounter (those detached from the world of critics
column11: I mean) it sounds "dated" or "old fashioned." This makes sense to me since while Forever Changes is a GREAT album
column12: the session musicians sound fairly separated from the band. This is okay since it still works great for the album. However
column13: with De Capo
column14: we simply have two extra musicians. These musicians bring classically-trained harpsichord
column15: jazzy saxophone and sparse/hip organ playing into the mix. As a result
column16: the extra musicians sound more organic; they actually sound as if they are a PART of the music. As a result
column17: the songs--at their very base--are given much more dimension and a sort of (for rock music
column18: anyway) inexplicable charm/class.   Whether it's the harpsichord-reinforced screamer rock of "Stephanie Knows Who
column19: the riff driven madness of Seven & Seven Is" or the semi-baroque "The Castle
column20: a listener quickly becomes aware that you're listen to music written by someone whose musical knowledge extends beyond doo-wop and mere psychedelics. (Though the music most certainly isn't devoid of these influences.) You hear showtunes, classical music and jazz all mixed into the cauldron and dispensed through a healthy medium of great pop music. Even with Revolution, while it may not be a piece of clever songwriting, it still gives the musicians to showcase the musical virtuosity that wouldn't readily be apparent in the songs they play. And finally, there's my personal favorite Que Vida
column21:
which never fails to make me feel as if I'm spiraling through the star-filled heavens. (Considering the amount of drugs taken during the writing of these songs, I wouldn't be surprised if Lee were feeling the same thing.)   All in all, this is an amazingly creative psychedelic masterpiece that is frequently overlooked thanks to its successor. I really do not have to say much about the aftermath since the rest, as they say, is history.   R.I.P Arthur Le

column1: I had an aching back for about five years
column2: mostly in my lower back and sometines in my mid and upper back. I made the usual rounds between doctors
column3: specialists
column4: chiropractors
column5: accupuncturists
column6: and so on. The pain was always there
column7: sometimes better sometimes worse. I used to wake up in pain and stiff most mornings.  One day I read an article about Dr. Sarno's work and decided to persue it further. I read his books and noticed some improvement in my pain and stiffness. But for whatever reason
column8: I just could not get rid of the pain.  Then I read Amir's book. I just made so much more sense to read the effectiveness of Sarno's method witin the context of his recovery. Just reading his story gave me a lot of hope. I tried his recovery plan and was amazed how quickly it worked. I never thought eating ice cream could cure my back.  Now 9 weeks later
column9: I am almost completely free of pain and very happy. I know the reviews for Sarno and Amir books are mixed
column10: but it worked for me and I if you like ice cream
column11: you should definitely try it.

column1: As I've stated many times before
column2: there was three types of music I listened to growing up. Innovative British
column3: pop American and unique Canadian. Unique didn't mean it was better but your perspective was different depending on which part of North America you were from. We had cancon (Canadian content) rules for radio meaning that a certain amount of airplay had to be devoted to Canadian talent. Unfortunately most of this talent couldn't or didn't break into the lucrative American market and its too bad as a lot of it was very good. Lighthouse "One Fine Morning" was a smash hit here along with the likes of "Pretty Lady
column4: Take it Slow

column6: Hats Off to the Stranger

column11: Devil You
column12: Wild Eyes
column13: Runnin' Wild
column14: Oh my Lady" etc. etc. etc. The Buoy's "Timothy" was admittedly a strange little ditty but it got past the censors of the time and was a catchy tune. Ex Smith member Gayle McCormick's "It's a Crying Shame" was also a big hit here as well as its flip side "If Only You Believe" which was also recorded by The Free Movement. Check out some of the groups I've mentioned. You may be pleasantly surprised. Enjoy

 The good: This book is quite well written.  Unlike most poker books, there is little jargon, which would make it quite valuable for a beginner.  Navarro's ideas are laid out in a very clear manner.  As other reviewers have stated, Navarro's insights are great and will help your poker game (as it has helped mine.)  The bad: It may just have been my expectations, but I was hoping for some activities designed to put the observation techniques into practice.  I also would have liked to have seen some clearer poker situations, like in Dan Harrington's books.  The visual examples provided in this book are all pictures of Navarro (except for a few of a woman to point out some gender specific tells.)  The only problem with this if we are to put this information into practice, we need to be used to looking for them on different people.  None of my problems with this book outweigh the positives.  I would like to see Navarro come out with a companion DVD.  This is a must-read, and goes well with Caro's Book of Tells

column9: each situation

column14: comforting

column16: I was finding myself highly interested
column17: enriched
column18: and feeling more positive about the few grim situations in my otherwise happy life! And I do think it could be a source of positive influence for anyone. No

column1: Contrary to some reviewers
column2: I felt the background of American atrocities added depth and understanding to the book. Does it make excuses for what the Japanese did? Absolutely not. Does it provide a framework for understanding the thinking of the people of that era? Yes. Just understanding the concept of "bringing civilization to the world" in both American and Japanese eyes is important. All too often we put ourselves on a the golden throne and never want to admit that we have been cruel to those we dominated. This book provides a very personal look at a few young men that lived and died for their country. It also provides graphic detail about the attrociites of war waged by a society ruled by fear of reprisal. A real eye-opener

column1: I strongly recommend new parents thoughtfully consider Baby Wise in developing your parenting style.  Now parents of a 5-month old
column2: we used parent directed feeding (PDF from Baby Wise) from the day we left the hospital and have been pleased with the results. BabyWise claims that that the PDF method will often result in happy
column3: well adjusted
column4: satisfied
column5: children that are pleasant to be around. We have found this to be the case.  My one gripe with the book is the lack of scientific
column6: empirical studies on the PDF parenting style. Unfortunately
column7: the book (and I) can only give anecdotal evidence of the merits of PDF based on personal experiences.   Born in the 25th percentile weight/height
column8: our little one was on a predictable schedule within a week
column9: consistently sleeping (7 hours) through the night within 7 weeks and has been sleeping 11 hours at night since 12 weeks. When in public
column10: we often get comments that our baby "is so happy" and "content." We go out to eat several times a week - without more than smiles and laughs (we have only left a restaurant once - but were able to do so before he cried). We house-hunted 9 hours a day for a week (in and out of the car 10-15 times) and our real estate agent never heard the baby cry - no pacifier. We have been on five multi-hour plane trips without any more than a giggle and coo. One friend was reluctant to hold our baby because she said that "babies always cry when I hold them." Our little one was pleasant and smiley. Does our baby ever cry? Of course! He cries at least one time every day (usually during his predictable "fussy time" - a 45 minute stretch before bedtime.) When he does cry
column11: diagnosing the problem is pretty simple with PDF (I'll let you read the book to find out how) - and I still haven't figured out how to differentiate types of crys as the hospital suggested. Just as indicated in Baby Wise
column12: after being put to bed at 9pm
column13: our little one wakes up at about 6:30am singing and cooing and goes back to sleep within 30 minutes. At 7:45am
column14: he wakes up again and greets us with a smile when we walk in the room. Our baby gained weight and height predictably throughout his first few months
column15: moving into the 50th percentile weight/height at his last visit.  My sister and several of our friends have used Baby Wise with similar results.   Is Baby Wise for everyone? - Probably not. If you enjoy structure and organization and are accustomed to being on a regular schedule yourself
column16: your parenting style will probably mesh nicely with Baby Wise. If you consider yourself a free spirit who enjoys responding to the unpredictability that life often brings
column17: then you will probably find Baby Wise to be restrictive to your parenting style. In fact
column18: we have friends who did not use Baby Wise and ended up with happy
column19: pleasant children as well.  Does Baby Wise CAUSE babies to be pleasant and happy? I don't know
column20: but it did work for us and I can only imagine how difficult parenthood would be for us without the principles explained in the book.

column4: insightful

column6: small-town
column7: edge dweller--ski bum
column8: river guide
column9: desert rat
column10: bus driver
column11: construction worker
column12: teacher
column13: newspaper columnist
column14: environmental and social activist and more--Wright has his thumb on the political
column15: cultural and spiritual life of small Rocky Mountain tourist towns like no other writer I know. While heavily influenced by Edward Abbey
column16: Wright's "rants" are his own
column17: in no way an imitation of anyone else. And best of all
column18: like Abbey
column19: Ken Wright has the sense of humor essential to make his ranting not only bearable
column20: but brilliant. If New York had any true book sense or any social and literary conscience--and if American readers had a bit more intelligence and open-minded curiosity--the big houses would be competing to sign writers like Wright and books like "Why I'm Against it All." But they don't
column21: and they won't. Nor will you likely see such small-publisher titles by "regional" writers prominently displayed in the big chain bookstores
column22: if they carry them at all. That's why local independent booksellers and Amazon.com are absolutely essential to the future of free speech
column23: creativity
column24: new talent and truth in America today. We must support them all
