column1: The issue of life's origins has long been troubling to scientists and lay observers alike.  When Charles Darwin wrote to Joseph Hooker that life likely formed in "some warm little pond" from elemental chemicals
column2: he set in motion years of study by countless researchers.  The question hinged on what was necessary to initiate "the spark of life".  Wills and Bada recount much of the work done to explain that obscure beginning.  For them
column3: the pivotal event is the famous Miller-Urey experiment of the 1950s.  First hailed as a
column4: perhaps "the"
column5: major breakthrough
column6: it was challenged and suffered from more updated information.  The authors revive the original concept
column7: enlarging it to restore its validity.  The means they use to achieve this is two-pronged: an investigation of life from "the bottom up" matched by another from "the top down".     Wills and Bada clearly wish to update the reading public in what has transpired in "origins of life" research since Stanley Miller zapped his own "little pond" in a sealed flask.   They acknowledge the objections later researchers posed about Earth's early environment.  They also confront the scenarios offered by Graham Cairns Smith and Gunter Wachtershauser.  The former suggested organic compounds might "learn" replication from clay crystals
column8: while the latter suggested the energy transfer methods associated with iron pyrites would support metabolic paths prior to the formation of cells.  Wachtershauser's mechanism
column9: they admit
column10: works admirably in the environment of sea-floor vents
column11: which were almost certainly present on the early Earth.  Yet
column12: attractive as both suggestions are
column13: the authors find updated versions of the original Miller-Urey more convincing.    The issue is
column14: of course
column15: Darwin's evolution by natural selection.  How early in life's beginnings could "selection" begin its winnowing process?  Building up molecules that will ultimately establish life-sustaining forms is unsatisfactory.  In order to function
column16: selection must have replication and variation in place.  The replication means sustained patterns of one form
column17: while variation suggests many types of forms allowing selection to take place in a stable environment.  That
column18: insist the authors
column19: means something like a gene must have been established reasonably early in life.  Since a gene's task is the production of proteins which accelerate the process
column20: there must have been a feedback loop system in action.  For some
column21: this structure suggests an early form of RNA
column22: leading to what they call "the RNA world".  The authors contend that RNA
column23: even in simple form
column24: is still too complex and fragile a molecule to have survived Earth's harsh conditions.  Instead
column25: they propose what they deem a "Peptide Nucleic Acid" or "PNA".  Not suffering RNA's delicate nature
column26: PNA in various forms could find havens in tidal pools
column27: tenaciously bound to rocks and forming oily films as protection against desiccating sunlight.  Thus Darwin's "warm little pond" finds vindication 150 years later
column28: buttressed by Miller and Urey's experiment and better understanding of biochemical processes.  All this may sound like intimidating reading.  It's far from that.  The authors have gone to some effort to keep the language in this work clear and explicit.  They build their case carefully
column29: leaving the reader in no doubt of their intention and the significance of their points.  They provide reasonably expressed counters to other proposals
column30: carefully explaining the reasons for their own objections to earlier hypotheses.  Beyond these considerations
column31: they also discuss the possibilities of extra-terrestrial life
column32: particularly that on Mars and satellites of the giant planets
column33: Jupiter and Saturn.  To enhance this discussion
column34: a number of William Hartmann's paintings are included.  They are lovely
column35: but add little to the discussion.  Other illustrative material is more cogent to the theme.  One might also wish that the authors had found a synonym for "primeval soup".  I lost count of the number of times it's used.  The book is a worthwhile read
column36: but isn't the final answer on the questions of life's origins.  [stephen a. haines - Ottawa
column37: Canada

column1: I have read nearly all of Michael Connelly's Bosch novels
column2: and I would say that CITY OF BONES is one of the better ones in the series.   I don't think this novel rivals the best Bosch books like THE CONCRETE BLONDE and THE LAST COYOTE.  But this novel is better than novels like ANGEL FLIGHT and the subpar DARKNESS MORE THAN NIGHT.  This novel is essentially a "cold case" mystery involving the recently discovered bones of a young child who was murdered over twenty years ago.  Bosch tries to get to the bottom of the child's murder
column3: and uncovers a lot of family secrets along the way.  I found the plot realistic and highly interesting and I thought Connelly did a good job with the story.  This is a real page-turner.  The most annoying aspect of this book is the romantic subplot
column4: which seems forced and underdeveloped.  I also find it unconvincing that Bosch
column5: a man in his fifties
column6: would have a beautiful woman in her mid-thirties throwing herself at him.  I was also highly disappointed with how this relationship was resolved.  In my opinion
column7: Connelly has never done a convincing job of creating a believable romantic relationship for Bosch.  Overall
column8: though
column9: CITY OF BONES is a great read and much better than other crime novels out there.  Highly recommended

column1: Will Durant's "Our Oriental Heritage" is the first of eleven volumes
column2: which make for his superb macro-history the Story of Civilization.  He begins with an analysis of the origins of civilization
column3: and then moves on with a survey of Near Eastern civilizations (Sumeria
column4: Egypt
column5: Babylonia
column6: Assyria
column7: Judea
column8: and Persia).  Durant focuses on all the Mesopotamian civilizations from their rise and fall
column9: and deals with Egypt from the earliest kings to the death of Alexander.  Then he moves into the Far East
column10: where he handles Indian
column11: Chinese
column12: and Japanese civilization to the contemporary world of Will Durant.  This excellent overview of Oriental culture will broaden any Occidental mans' perspective on just how his culture and civilization arose.  It will allow him to question many western ideals and values and compel him to further understand these remarkable civilizations to which we are so highly indebted.  Durant's work will
column13: in a sense
column14: place the eastern mind in the western man while reading through these pages
column15: even if it is only for a moment.  This work sets the tone for the rest
column16: so get to reading and enjoy the ride from here to the Age of Napoleon

column1: Sea of Glory by Nathaniel Philbrick is the fascinating
column2: true story of the US Navy's South Sea Exploring Expedition to the Pacific that began in 1838.  There were several goals to this ambitious trip: they were to go as far south on the globe as possible
column3: survey the Polynesian Islands
column4: survey the Columbia River and San Francisco Bay
column5: and have scientists collect samples of new flora
column6: fauna
column7: etc.  While the Ex. Ex. started off as following in the footsteps of Captain Cook
column8: the officer in charge of the expedition
column9: Charles Wilkes
column10: quickly morphed into Captain Bligh.    The Ex. Ex. accomplished quite a bit.  Wilkes "discovered" Antarctica and even gave the continent its name.  They charted many island groups including Fiji
column11: Tahiti
column12: Samoa
column13: and Hawaii
column14: as well as the Columbia River
column15: Puget Sound and the San Francisco Bay.  The scientists on board (some of the best of that time period) made many unique discoveries and brought back 40 tons of specimens and artifacts.  Even the philologist on board did much to identify Indian language and preserve oral history.  And the crew saw countless wonders of nature including icebergs over 830 feet high
column16: the Aurora Australis
column17: active volcanoes and oceans that looked like they were churning fire.    Unfortunately
column18: Lt. Charles Wilkes made the four years of the Ex. Ex. a living hell.  He was a jealous
column19: petty
column20: paranoid
column21: insecure
column22: arrogant
column23: overbearing and vengeful egomaniac.  He wasn't the first choice for the Ex. Ex. (or the second or third). He did have good survey skills
column24: but limited seamanship.  He was extremely jealous of anyone more knowledgeable or skilled than he.  His way of dealing with this was to trump up some bogus charge and then have the men sent back to the states (not an easy thing from Australia or Hawaii).  He loved the lash and insisted on punishing his crew in this manner
column25: and always with more lashes than allowed by naval law.  When the US Navy refused to promote him to captain and commodore (he had a squadron of 6 ships)
column26: Wilkes promoted himself when the Ex. Ex. reached the Pacific and there was little chance of running into other American ships. When it was apparent that the expedition would take an additional year
column27: many of the sailors signed off and left.  But Wilkes would not let the marines do the same.  He had them beaten on a daily basis until they realized that if they didn't acquiesce
column28: they would eventually be beaten to death.  It wasn't long before he alienated all the officers and men of the expedition.  You'll have to read the book to see if Wilkes ever got his due.  Sea of Glory is filled with drawings
column29: photos and maps
column30: but it would have been more helpful to have the maps all in one location.  It was difficult to keep flipping back to find maps of specific island groups.  Also
column31: while I grew up in a sailing family and have a basic knowledge of sailing terms
column32: Philbrick gives us liberal doses of sailing vocabulary without explanation including hawse holes
column33: capstans
column34: taffrels
column35: davits
column36: cutwaters and stoppers--to name just a few.  Philbrick spends much time describing almost all of their experiences while at sea
column37: but there is virtually nothing about California and the surveying of the San Francisco Bay.  So while I thoroughly enjoyed Sea of Glory
column38: I felt these deficiencies kept me from giving it five stars.

column1: Up to this point
column2: this is probably Floyd's best greatest hits compilation
column3: and it does contain some pretty good tracks
column4: but I think it leaves off too many crucial tracks to be considered the best Pink Floyd greatest hits compilation.  Most of the important tracks from the Syd Barrett era are all pretty much included
column5: though I'd have liked to see tracks like Lucifer Sam and Interstellar Overdrive included as well.  One important track that should have been included is Roger Waters' first composition for the band
column6: Take Up Thy Stethoscope and Walk.  Seeing as he'd go on to the writer for the band throughout it's prime
column7: I think it would have been a neat glimpse into his first material for the band.  Moving on
column8: I also think that "Free Four
column9: Floyd's first song to receive significant airplay in the US should have been included.  While it may not be a huge track today, it did bring them to the spotlight in the US, and is just as crucial as any other.  Some other complaints of mine stem from the tracks they included from DSOTM.  Time and Money are both included, but where's Brain Damage / Eclipse?  One of the first Floyd songs I remember hearing from a young age, and possibly the one that got me into them is not included, but tracks like Great Gig in the Sky and Us and Them, while great tracks, aren't quite as important to a compilation like this, when Brain Damage / Eclipse should have been included instead.  From Animals, we have Sheep
column10: which is my personal least favorite on the album, and not a track I ever remember hearing before I got into Floyd.  Why not Dogs
column11: or Pigs (Three Different Ones)" instead? Much better tracks.  And where's "Young Lust" and "Run Like Hell" from the Wall?  What about "Not Now John" from The Final Cut?  Like I said
column12: while a fairly good compilation
column13: I think it misses a lot of crucial tracks to Floyd's history.  Sure
column14: it's still Floyd
column15: and all Floyd is going to be awesome anyway
column16: but if you're going to make it reflect over Floyd's 40 year history
column17: then better make sure all you have all their best

column1: This razor's best virtue for me is its ability to cut a thick beard without clogging like the multi blade cartridges out there. I always dreaded shaving after a hunting or fishing trip. Even the old Gillette twist-open requires that it be partially opened to properly rinse out the cream and whisker sludge. This guy has a nice round cavity underneath each cutting edge that allows water to wash everything away. Even shaking it in a bowl will clear it most of the time. If it should clog
column2: one can blow it out quite easily. I have only used the lower settings
column3: and they are all I seem to need with good blades. The Gillette blades sold in the US are horrible
column4: BTW. Use Merkur blades or Swedish Gillettes for the best shave.  My only complaint is that the alignment marks to match up the top and body are faint
column5: and the adjustment marks do not line up properly
column6: and I am forced to do math to get repeatability. I have higher expectations for German engineering and the price.  This thing is overpriced for what it is
column7: but a good shave is worth a lot
column8: and you only buy it once
